https://www.cnbc.com/2025/10/18/secondha: The global secondhand luxury market is experiencing explosive growth, projected to reach $360 billion by 2030 from $210 billion currently, expanding at 10% annually—three times faster than the firsthand luxury market according to a Boston Consulting Group report. As counterfeit manufacturing becomes increasingly sophisticated with "superfakes" that can fool even luxury brands themselves, authentication has emerged as the defining factor separating credible resale platforms from competitors. Major platforms like Singapore-based Carousell and South Korea's Bunjang are implementing advanced verification systems combining traditional visual inspections with AI technology and scientific equipment, with Bunjang claiming 99.9% authentication accuracy. Consumer trust has become paramount in this market driven primarily by millennials and Gen Z seeking affordable access to luxury goods, with buyers willing to pay premium prices for authenticated items that come with money-back guarantees on authenticity.
https://www.cnbc.com/2025/10/17/proxy-ad: Top proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) is recommending that Tesla shareholders vote against CEO Elon Musk's nearly $1 trillion pay package at the company's annual meeting scheduled for November 5, 2025. The "mega performance equity award" is designed to retain Musk long-term and has what ISS describes as an "astronomical grant value" conditioned on far-reaching performance targets. While ISS acknowledges that achieving these targets would create enormous value for shareholders, they still oppose the massive compensation plan. Tesla is also scheduled to report its third-quarter results on Wednesday ahead of the shareholder vote.
https://www.cnbc.com/2025/10/17/jim-cram: CNBC's Jim Cramer expects companies to post "better-than-expected" earnings reports next week, predicting another strong week that will continue the market's three-year bull run. He outlined a detailed weekly gameplan covering specific companies including Coca-Cola, GE Aerospace, IBM, T-Mobile, Blackstone, and others, emphasizing that earnings rather than other factors are what truly drive stock movements. Cramer believes this earnings-driven rally will persist despite ongoing skepticism from bears and market doubters. He suggests that skeptics will continue to miss out on "phenomenal market moves" as companies deliver strong quarterly results.
